articles.headline: Top Bidder for Tribune Newspapers Is an Influential Liberal Donor
articles.snippet: The Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss helped build a sophisticated behind-the-scenes operation that attacked Republicans and promoted Democratic causes.
articles.abstract: The Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss helped build a sophisticated behind-the-scenes operation that attacked Republicans and promoted Democratic causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before he emerged as a potential champion of journalism with his bid for Tribune Publishing, the Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss quietly created a sophisticated political operation to advance progressive policy initiatives and the Democrats who support them.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Biden to Withdraw All Combat Troops From Afghanistan by Sept. 11
articles.snippet: After years of arguing against an extended military presence in Afghanistan, President Biden is doing things his way, with the deadline for withdrawal set for the 20th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.
articles.abstract: After years of arguing against an extended military presence in Afghanistan, President Biden is doing things his way, with the deadline for withdrawal set for the 20th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will withdraw American combat troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11, declaring an end to the nation’s longest war and overruling warnings from his military advisers that the departure could prompt a resurgence of the same terrorist threats that sent hundreds of thousands of troops into combat over the past 20 years.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Police Officer Who Shot and Killed Daunte Wright Was Training Others
articles.snippet: Kimberly A. Potter was a 26-year veteran of the force in a Minneapolis suburb and president of a police union.
articles.abstract: Kimberly A. Potter was a 26-year veteran of the force in a Minneapolis suburb and president of a police union.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CENTER, Minn. — Officer Kimberly A. Potter was in the midst of a routine training day on Sunday, demonstrating her decades of policing know-how to less experienced officers in the Brooklyn Center Police Department.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Capitol Police Told to Hold Back on Riot Response on Jan. 6, Report Finds
articles.snippet: Despite being tipped that “Congress itself is the target” on Jan. 6, Capitol Police were ordered not to use their most powerful crowd-control weapons, according to a scathing new watchdog report.
articles.abstract: Despite being tipped that “Congress itself is the target” on Jan. 6, Capitol Police were ordered not to use their most powerful crowd-control weapons, according to a scathing new watchdog report.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Capitol Police had clearer advance warnings about the Jan. 6 attack than were previously known, including the potential for violence in which “Congress itself is the target.” But officers were instructed by their leaders not to use their most aggressive tactics to hold off the mob, according to a scathing new report by the agency’s internal investigator.

articles.headline: In Early Testimony for Defense, Witness Says Chauvin’s Force Was ‘Justified’
articles.snippet: The defense also presented body camera video from a previous arrest of George Floyd, part of its strategy to shift the jurors’ focus to his use of illicit drugs.
articles.abstract: The defense also presented body camera video from a previous arrest of George Floyd, part of its strategy to shift the jurors’ focus to his use of illicit drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A police officer approached a car with George Floyd in the front seat, and Mr. Floyd started to panic. While officers ordered him to spit out a pill he was trying to swallow, he repeatedly begged them not to shoot him.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Hundreds of Companies Unite to Oppose Voting Limits, but Others Abstain
articles.snippet: Amazon, Google, G.M. and Starbucks were among those joining the biggest show of solidarity by businesses over legislation in numerous states.
articles.abstract: Amazon, Google, G.M. and Starbucks were among those joining the biggest show of solidarity by businesses over legislation in numerous states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives signed on to a new statement released on Wednesday opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Coinbase’s Public Listing Is a Cryptocurrency Coming-Out Party
articles.snippet: With acceptance from traditional investors, a profitable start-up that eases transactions is offering proof of the industry’s staying power.
articles.abstract: With acceptance from traditional investors, a profitable start-up that eases transactions is offering proof of the industry’s staying power.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Digital currency, once mocked as a tool for criminals and reckless speculators, is sliding into the mainstream.

articles.headline: Afghans Wonder ‘What About Us?’ as U.S. Troops Prepare to Withdraw
articles.snippet: Many Afghans fear that without the umbrella of American protection, the country will be unable to preserve its modest gains toward democracy and women’s rights.
articles.abstract: Many Afghans fear that without the umbrella of American protection, the country will be unable to preserve its modest gains toward democracy and women’s rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A female high school student in Kabul, Afghanistan’s war-scarred capital, is worried that she won’t be allowed to graduate. A pomegranate farmer in Kandahar wonders if his orchards will ever be clear of Taliban land mines. A government soldier in Ghazni fears he will never stop fighting.

articles.headline: With Earnings Soaring, Wall Street Banks See Economic Boom Ahead
articles.snippet: The banks said they released large chunks of money that had been set aside to cushion themselves from losses caused by the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The banks said they released large chunks of money that had been set aside to cushion themselves from losses caused by the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mood on Wall Street is decidedly jubilant.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, Matt Phillips and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Bernard Madoff, Architect of Largest Ponzi Scheme in History, Is Dead at 82
articles.snippet: His enormous fraud left behind a devastating human toll and paper losses totaling $64.8 billion.
articles.abstract: His enormous fraud left behind a devastating human toll and paper losses totaling $64.8 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernard L. Madoff, the onetime senior statesman of Wall Street who in 2008 became the human face of an era of financial misdeeds and missteps for running the largest and possibly most devastating Ponzi scheme in financial history, died on Wednesday in a federal prison hospital in Butner, N.C. He was 82.
